definition: Quality of processes used to investigate breaches, arbitrate outcomes, and enforce remedies without bias.

positive_examples: Cases enter via standard channels with tracking IDs.
Panels include balanced representation and neutral chairs.
Evidence packets are shared with all parties simultaneously.
Hearings are recorded and transcripts distributed.
Interim measures are proportional and reversible.
Decisions cite treaty clauses and telemetry.
Remediation plans include timelines and owners.
Appeal paths are documented and respected.
Retaliation against complainants is forbidden and enforced.
Historical precedent is referenced for consistency.
Translation support is provided for all languages.
Learning reviews follow every major case.
Remedy implementation is monitored by the collective.
negative_examples: Complaints require backchannel favors to be heard.
Panels are stacked with one tribe's allies.
Evidence is drip-fed to disadvantage respondents.
Decisions cite vague notions rather than clauses.
Remediation plans are oral promises only.
Similar cases get wildly different outcomes.
Translation is ad hoc, leading to misunderstanding.
Remedies go unmonitored once headlines fade.
training_hints.disambiguation: Quality of processes used to investigate breaches, arbitrate outcomes, and enforce remedies without bias.
